title: Chihuly Garden and Glass, Seattle

My guest was a well known painter from Laguna Woods, California, here in Seattle for a visit. Knowing her devotion to form and color I took her to the Chihuly exhibit at Seattle Center. Exceptional experience, Fills the senses with beauty and inspiration. I would recommend this highly.

title: The Museum of Flight, Seattle
address: 9404 East Marginal Way South, Seattle, WA 98108
review_list:
If you like airplanes or at least appreciate them because of design, color, or history, you need to check this place out! They have WWI, WWII, Vietnam, Korean war, early 1900s, and modern planes from around the world! They also have a Space Center with the - THE - shuttle used to train astronauts in Houston. On the first Thursday...


More  



Visited here three times so far and always satisfied. Don't forget the great outdoor exhibitions including a Concorde and a former Air Force One jet !

Have visited Museum on several occasions. Always enjoy new and different displays. More than just Boeing products. Recommend for all age levels.

I visit the Museum of Flight about every 3 years whether I think I need to or not and each time I discover something new and enlightening about aerospace. It is a wonderful place for children of all ages and like any good museum I sometimes feel guilty for the amount of time I spend browsing the exhibits.

If you are interested in the history of aviation and in Boeing, you will enjoy this museum. It is about 20 minutes south of downtown Seattle. There's not much else in that area--gift shop, cafeteria on-site. If you head east afterwards, you can take a nice walk around Seward Park and get great views of Lake Washington, Bellevue, Seattle. Driving...


More  



This is a museum you can go to often and still learn something new or be amazed at a plane or piece of history you may have missed. Give plenty of time and don't miss the Red Barn!

The Museum of Flight has been compared to the greatest Aerospace museums in the World and I would not disagree. Starting with Bill Boeing's 1st production facility, to the only existing Space Shuttle Simulator it is all here. There are multiple wings (oops sorry for the pun!) WWI, Space, Jets, Commercial, Defense etc. Most exhibits and planes are inside but...

When my grandson visited me in August, I took him to the Museum of Flight along with some friends and their children....it was a hit! Since he just turned 13, sometimes he is 'bored' by everything, and this trip he was very interested and excited!

If aviation interests you, this museum mustn't be missed. It is beautifully designed and contains wonderful airplanes.

Planes, rockets, aerospace and anything that flies!! Huge collection amazing to sit and watch the planes take off and land! Go around sea fair might just catch the blue angles taking off or landing!

title: Washington State Ferries, Seattle
review_list:
I've been traveling on the WA State Ferry system for 33 years; haven't been on all of them, but I've frequented 3 of them many times. Except for excessively long lines around a few choice holidays, I've never had a reason to complain. The peacefulness and beauty of the changing scenery at anytime of year, is certainly worth the price...

Short sailing- awesome view crossing over to Clinton. Staff is super friendly and love how motorbike can go straight to the front to pay and get priority boarding! Thanks to the friendly driver that told us that!

We rode the ferries a number of times while in Seattle to get to Bremerton mainly. Wish we would have had a schedule before we started, make sure you get one. We had to wait an hour since we had just missed one. There is food and drink available and felt very safe. Makes for beautiful landscape while on the...


More  



I use both the Edmonds/Kingston ferry and the Seattle/Bainbridge Island Ferry. The ferry and the crew are very nice and respectful. However the cost to purchase food is too much for the quality of food you receive. It's not even as good as the Hospital Cafeteria.

The ferries are comfortable and safe and a wonderful way (sometimes the only way) to travel in the Puget Sound.

Seldom delayed, a smidge pricey, but very frequent, user-friendly, and comfortable. The arrival times are published on line, so keep that in mind when choosing your route.

Our dream vacation into the San Juan Islands for kayaking and orca watching required some logistical planning. By well-documented, I mean that their website gave us all the information we needed to pre-plan and execute our travels hassle and mistake free: from...

Absolutely love taking ferries. This one in particular, to Bainbridge Island, was fantastic. Great views of the city, islands, mountains and Mount Rainier. Even saw some whales! We loved taking the ferry and would love to come back and take it again if we had the chance! Such a fun, unique experience! We loved the beautiful views and all of the decks we could walk on! Washington State Ferries could learn a lot from BC Ferries. not a pleasant experience. lines were long. food options limited. workers were quite friendly is the best I can say.

title: Pike Place Market, Seattle
address: Between Pike and Pine sts. at First Ave., Seattle, WA 98101
review_list:
The Market is always a great place to go. We especially enjoy the show at the fish market. They are so good with the crowd. Also love the Spice store and the variety of herbs and teas offered. We were there on a Monday so many stalls were not open. All in all it was a good time.

This is always an experience and never exactly the same experience. There is a lot to explore, many shopping opportunities and usually some form of entertainment.

The Pike Place market is one of the oldest public markets in the United States still operating. It will be packed with fresh vegetables, fresh flowers, fresh fish, spices, tourists and locals. At all times there will be venders with everything from tiny hand made flowers from an artist from Thailand, great market bags that will last for years, lovely...

This is one of my favorite places in Seattle. The fresh vegetables and meats are unparalleled. The flowers are amazing and the atmosphere is very eclectic and fun. I love taking visitors there.

Even if you don't want to purchase anything at Pike Place Market, you will find it an interesting place to visit. Pike Place is a multi-level maze of small shops, cafes and produce stands that offer an ambiance which cannot be matched anywhere else in Seattle. It reminds me of the old Agora in Athens and parts of the Grand...


More  



Great walk exploring the market and all of the vendors. Beautiful flowers (fresh and dried) at superb prices. Some of the tastiest preserves, freshest seafood and friendly vendors. I wish I'd had more time to explore!

When in Seattle, you must go and visit Pikes Place, there is something for everyone, in all cultures. There is a lot of food places, from vegetarians to seafood to anything. Very good place

So the world famous market is fun and tons of stores. Really just an overpriced tourist trap at this point but fun anyways. I would definitely visit and walk around but eat and shop in different parts of town.

Great views from all the seats. A good place to take family and friends to catch a game. Vendors surround the entrances and some walk the aisles selling food and drink.

Solid ballpark to watch baseball. I went twice and fans were friendly. Ballpark food is ok and prices are average for a ballpark. Public transportation drops off near stadium and there are a few decent bars and restaurants outside stadium.

this is a nice small ball park that has everything to offer with great food and drinks and not a bad seat in the house even when your eating the ball field is right there

title: Kerry Park, Seattle
address: 250 W Highland Dr, Queen Ann Hill, Seattle, WA 98119
review_list:
We've probably all seen at least one photo shot from this Seattle vantage point. Depending on the weather and lunar cycle, It is possible to capture the Seattle City Skyline with Mt Rainier and a full moon against a sky-blue backdrop. Went there a couple times at weekends just to get some along time. It's a quiet and nice place. The only thing is that it does not have restrooms around. I had an emergency situation and had to walk to the nearest Trader Joe's to get myself relieved.

The viewing area is very small but the park has multiple levels with a playground at the bottom. Great place to bring friends visiting Seattle, right up the hill from Dicks.

One of the most photographed views in Seattle. When national news crews like NBC, CNN etc. broadcast from Seattle it is almost always from here. If you can go at sunset (weather cooperating) for extraordinary views of the city and Elliot Bay.

One of the very points of the city. Perfect photo opp. Any time of year. Lake Union, Downtown Seattle, and the Space Needle.

Great view of the city with the Space Needle and Mt Rainier in the distance. A very nice area for walking.

The view is amazing from the park!!! It makes the place worth visiting. I took some great pictures there, I love them!!!!

This should be a "must see" for everyone. The vantage point affords a great view of Seattle. The drive to Kerry Park is through some nice areas and even that is pleasant.

If you want to take the "post card" picture that you always see, go to Kerry Park. On a clear day, you can see the enormous beauty of Mount Rainier. Go here for a picture perfect moment of the city.

Kerry Park in Seattle,Washington is a nice & beautiful park! Great scenery of Seattle! Good view on a sunny day! Queen Anne is a nice neighborhood in Seattle! Beautiful houses in the neighborhood too! Kerry Park is a popular & well-knowned tourist attraction in Seattle!

title: Space Needle, Seattle
address: 400 Broad Street, Broad St. and Fifth Ave. N, Seattle, WA 98109
review_list:
Make reservations because the lines can be quite long here. The restaurant rotates so the view changes all the time, incredible. The food is good and the brunch menus allows you to enjoy a nice variety.

The Space Needle is an iconic landmark best seen from a distance. I love seeing the needle from a ferry ride or just when driving in a car. No need to pay money just to go to the top in my opinion.

The space needle was very cool but hard to get pictures. Better bet is to buy lunch on the 50th floor, they there is not charge to go up to the top. Pictures are much better from inside the restaurant.

In fairness I didn't go to top of the space needle. Reason for not going up was really long line with children screaming and acting up hence the average review. It is a cool site to see from all around the city but actually visiting it I'll pass!!

I love the Space Needle and when any friends come in to visit, that is a must-see place! Although the prices seem to continue to rise, I've found if you go at lunchtime instead, it is more reasonable price-wise. But the views are absolutely stunning no matter when you go! This is always on my list to visit!

see all of the city from this spot. Great dining experience at the top but has a long waiting list to eat there.

We did not book tickets in advance to enjoy the space needle, which is why we give it a 3 stars. November is not considered peak season and it was still busy. Our schedule was tight, which is why we could not get to the top.

It's best to get your tickets in advance (internet or on site, but you'll have to return). We've booked our tickets on site in the morning and were able to visit the needle in the afternoon. This is one of ' man made marvel ' you can get full Panoramic view of city , very exiting , specially in night
Walking on edge of tower is amazing experience

title: Benaroya Hall, Seattle
review_list:
inside is very nice. outside is major bus stops. many people and homeless all wait outside. made the area is too crowed.

I was recently here for the holidays, for the Holiday Pops show, and it was my first time. The space was beautiful and the musicians were amazing. The interior is modern with clean lines, but comfortable with a warm color palette. Would definitely recommend to anyone visiting.

A beautiful environment for music, but the sound has disappointed my husband and I every time. Maybe our expectations have been too high--he attended so many Santa Fe Operas, I enjoyed Boston. But the acoustics have not been what we enjoy, regardless of our seating.

This is a wonderful place and I doubt if there is a bad seat in the house. The seat are comfortable with lots of room to spread out. No problem having a middle seat here as one is not crowded and can get up to visit the rest room and not disturb your neighbor. Excellent acoustics too.

Great place to hear great and unusual music. One time we watched the Matrix while they played the music. Awesome!

Whether it's the Holiday Special shows, Favorites Artists or Book Authors, this venue is superb! Great acoustics!

Benaroya Hall is a must see. The Chihuly chandeliers in the lobby are amazing. And, if time allows seeing a performance in the Hall is well worth the time. The acoustics are wonderful and the hall itself is beautiful

I don't know how many times I have been to Benaroya, but each time has been the most Wonderful experience of Grace. From the beautiful wonder filled music of the Strings, to the incredible presentations of a band, each experience has been fantastic.

The Benaroya Hall's acoustics are so fantastic that one can hear a pin drop...on stage or anywhere in the hall which is slightly distracting when one is listening to the world class symphony orchestra or any other performance or presentation. Luv to take my out of town guests to this location, especially, anyone not used to being near the ocean. In Seattle, this is very convenient and near where Sleepless in Seattle was filmed.
My prairie visitors are especially amazed.

title: Green Lake Park, Seattle

Seattle luxuriates in beautiful parks. Green Lake is among the best. It nicely accommodates walkers and runners. (Cyclists sort of dominate those on foot.) Dog-friendly (on a leash). The lake is scenic and, in fine weather, it's great for swimming and boating.

Cannot think of a nicer "Free" place to visit on a sunny weekday in Seattle. Place gets too crowded on weekends for my taste. We took guests here last September on a Tuesday Afternoon. They were so impressed! Park is clean with lots of water activities.

title: EMP Museum, Seattle

review_list:

As a huge Nirvana and Jimi Hendrix fan, this is a must do. Many TV screens with interviews and commentary about the bands a scene at the time. Plan on spending a few hours...

The EMP museum has an eclectic mix of collectables (of local billionaire, Paul Allen). There are rooms for exploring different artists and styles, plus rooms to experiment with instruments and sound equipment (our kids loved...

Lots of different things to see inside. If you like nirvana or Jimi Hendrix or playing instruments and at the same time seeing hello Kitty then you'll be very happy. The only thing I regret is that the place is huge but the visit is short

Interesting & unusual 'museum' well worth a visit, could spend hours in here. Nirvana exhibit is a must-see & the monorail is a cheap n easy ride into downtown

We decided to check out EMP and we were pleasantly surprised! There is music history to learn & places to explore. The interactive "sound booth" was very cool. You can play the musical instruments to your favorite song & even record a session. Worth checking out...

If you don't know who Starbuck and #6 are, and here's a hint, I'm not talking about coffee, maybe this isn't the museum for you. For the rest of us, this place is geek heaven. A real walk down sci-fi memory lane. OMG, is that the spinner from Blade Runner?? Yes, friends, it is.
Oh yes, there are also guitars...


More  



This is a wonderful attraction built by Paul Allen (one of Microsoft founders) that is a real treat for those who love music. You will find lots of history and fun thing to both see and do. There are many interactive activities in the museum.

I was mixed about this place. Don't get me wrong it's super nice but I'm just not seriously into the details of music. I love music but reading all about every famous musician or where this jacket was worn tended to overwhelm me. BUT NOT MY WIFE...she could have stayed there for hours and hours. She was fascinated.

Due to the short nature of my trip I was only able to see a few things during my visit to Seattle. This museum took up all my time and I regret nothing. We spent 4+ hours there and only stopped because they were closing. The horror and sci-fi exhibits were a nerd's wet dream. I was thoroughly enthralled. The...

title: CenturyLink Field, Seattle
address: Junction of I-5 and I-90, Seattle, WA
review_list:
We bought seasons tickets for the Seahawks 2015 season in the front row of Section 306 which were great. The roof awning just reaches out far enough that if you have Loge Seats in the upper 300 levels on the east and west sidelines, you're covered from the rain unless it's blowing really hard. People below us in the 100...


More  



The tours of the stadium have to be booked in person. We only had 3 days in Seattle and were not willing to risk not getting a tour at the time we needed.
To secure a tour, we paid for a private tour for our family of 3. The great thing about a tour is the ability to bring more...


More  



Home of the super bowl 48 champion Seahawks. If you haven't been to a game you must come to feel the electricity and the noise!! Where else can you create and earthquake or set s record for loudest fans. The electricity is amazing especially for a playoff game!!

There are signs around, but not very well marked to find parking garage. We were on 4th, then on 1st, and it is tricky, I think,+ to find the parking garage. The road splits for deliveries, then up for garage. I think this should be addressed and signage should be better established.

if you are a Seahawk Fan, you better visit the place, especially if there is a game. I visited in Jan, unfortunately there were no games to be played at that time, there is a shop next to the field, make sure you pass by to pick up what you can from SeaHawk accessories and clothes.

Went to the Boat Show at Century Link Field. Lots of different types of boats, small, big yachts, stuff.

I didn't really think it would be as loud as they say. It was though. We went with a group of Bears fans for the Bears vs. Seahawks. All of the fans were pretty nice to us and it was a pretty cool atmosphere. Plus they let you bring in your own food!

Been to a few Seahawks games and the stadium is well designed, the volume of the cheering is incredible, what an experience. The Seattle fans are very polite and very loud!

We have been Seahawk season ticket holders for 11 years. We love the game day experience especially now that there are more good bars and restaraunts in the area for pregame. My only negative comments about the Clink are that the beers are way overpriced, and there are few quality food selections inside the stadium for general fans. All of...


More  



This tour takes you to all of the highlights of this stadium. From the raising of the flag at the top of the stadium to the private parking for the players under the stadium. You will have the opportunity to check out a private suite, the broadcasters suite, the press room, the dressing rooms, and many other off limits area's...


More

title: Washington Park Arboretum, Seattle
review_list:
The Arboretum is a wonderful place to visit. Walking amidst the gardens at any time of year is a pleasure.

Went to the Center for Urban Horticulture for 2 hours, then here for 2. Very nice arboretum. Lots of species to look at. Expect to do some walking.

Azalea Way is a wonderful stroll when the flowers are in bloom. In spring it's cherries, plums, azaleas. The Japanese garden across the street is worth a visit too.

The Washington Park Arboretum (managed by the University of Washington) is one of the largest parks in Seattle. The park is bisected by one through road which branches to parking near a visitor center as well as the Japanese Gardens. However, on a warm day when there hasn't been rain recently it can be a real chore to find parking,...


More  



Soon, very soon, the lovely winter garden will be in bloom. An easy walk from the parking lot and while any walk in this garden is great, the lovely, kind of tucked away winter garden is a very special thing. It rains here, sometimes for months and months and it is more often than not grey, grey, grey. But a...


More  



Too much to see in a few minutes. Help is available with signs, staff, volunteers, and fellow. Check their schedule for special events. Park is situated along an old creek which empties into a bay of Lake Washington that was lowered the level of Lake Union when the ship canal was constructed.

we just visited the Japanese garden part of the arboretum. it was pouring rain but it was beautiful and worth it nonetheless. I can only imagine what it would be like on a sunny day. would have liked to sit on a bench and relaxed.

Whatever the season, there is much to see and explore at this gem of greenery and knowledge. Helpful staff at the visitor's center will get you started on exploring on your own or partaking of scheduled walks with a volunteer or staffer.

You can rent canoes at the bottom of the UW parking lot and then canoe over to the arboretum. It's so worth it especially when its blossoming. You can pull the canoe up and have a quick picnic too.

The park itself is free but the Japanese Garden has an entry fee.
We visited in fall and enjoyed the change of color and change of seasons. Highly recommend this place when Jap Maples are in glories reds and yellows.

title: Museum of History & Industry, Seattle
review_list:
We are from Seattle and finally got down to MOHAI's new home on Lake Union. It is excellent! Don't miss the movie on the Great Seattle Fire, a funny and engaging presentation!

The old Armory has been completely renovated and they did a great job. The museum has lots of pertinent and interesting displays about early Seattle. Very well done and in a nice location.

Fine location adjacent to too ship and boat museums, with lovely building and good collection of local historical artifacts. The 2015 prohibition exhibit was highly entertaining.

There was a model train expo going on while we were visiting so there were numerous children in there. Fun to watch, but wanted to move quickly. In doing so, missed out on several things. Seemed like a messy cluster due to number of people and exhibits. Advice - Do not go visit for relaxation during this expo unless you...


More  



Good for a half-day tour. I think we looked at all the exhibits in under 4 hours. Very interesting history. Best to start at top floor and work your way down in clock-wise fashion.

This was our first visit to this museum. It was two hours well spent as we got a very good overview of the history of Seattle. I learned a number of new things about the city.

Smashing displays to show you the history of Seattle. Very well laid out and very good value for money. We thought we'd only be there for about an hour but we got engrossed and spent about 3 hours here. It's an easy bus ride from downtown. Definitely recommended

This museum (referred to as the MOHAI) is a great little place to go to see the heritage of Seattle. The exhibits are very often interactive and for once they all work (so often these sorts of exhibits break due to exuberant kids playing on them) and give you the chance to learn at your own pace.
There are several...


More  



On a rainy day in Seattle we decided to check the MOHI. I was thoroughly impressed. Great variety of exhibits, that included a vast amount of information about Seattle and the NW. It was unique and interactive. I would definitely go back.

It's like a mini Seattle Smithsonian. There were a fair amount of interactive exhibits and if you're even a little proud of your city it would be a good place to take guests. Not to mention the setting is pretty wonderful. Aren't too many cities that boast two lakes right in downtown.

title: Seattle Center, Seattle
review_list:
The Seattle Center is the outgrowth of the World's Fair in the early 60s. The park setting is home to everything from Opera and ballet to theatre, the Chihuly Glass museum, a varied and extensive food court, even an ice skating rink in winter. The Space Needle overlooks the Center and is it's own attraction, though the proliferation of tall...


More  



In the area there are lots of activities, especially for children. There is the Pacific Science Centre, the Space Needle, Chihuly and Glass Garden and the EMH museum. Several places to eat food as well. Lots of seating in the area. Accessible to downtown either by walking (20-30min) or by monorail.

Your kids will love this place loads for them to play with experiment with. Plenty of places for parents to sit and let there kids run off there energy.

The Seattle Center has multiple tourist attractions (EMH Museum, Space Needle, and Pacific Science Center). There is also a nice food court to stop and eat. There Seattle Centers hosts multiple events throughout the year, so keep your eye on their schedule for something that looks fun.

We spent a lovely afternoon here. Used the monorail from the Westlake Centre which only took around 2 minutes and was very reasonably priced at $2.25 one-way. Beautifully kept area to wonder around and for children to play in. There are various exhibitions to visit and the Space Needle. Only downside is that these are quite expensive to get in...


More  



Its really nothing so good in the streets, else than the pike market, and museums, but everything closes too early, be aware to have dinner early if you are looking for something not too expensive. also starbucks close early not like in other cities.

All part of the Seattle experience! Went to the Gates Foundation, The Chihuly Garden. Took the Monorail. And ate in the Armory.

This is a fun thing to do if you are staying in downtown and wish to visit the Seattle Center. There is only 2 stops, it takes you from Westlake shopping area to the Seattle Center (space needle, children's museum, EMP, Pacific Science Center, Duck tour, etc).
It's fun if you have kids, and it costs only around $ 2.25...


More  



Space Needle and Chihuly Exhibition are certainly worth their tickets. There is a food court where you can purchase any type of food you desire. It is also a great place to people watch. A large fountain sits near the center and is a great place for pictures or to just sit and contemplate. I enjoyed my visit to downtown...


More  



If you are visiting the Space Needle and the glass museum, this is the quickest way to get back into downtown. It drops you off between Nordstrom's and Macy's at a mall.

title: Woodland Park Zoo, Seattle
review_list:
My wife loves, loves, loves to visit the zoo. We now live within walking distance so we have visited a lot lately. We've fed the giraffes but missed the feeding of the penguins (we'll try again later). For the second year in a row, we've attended the holiday lights event and thoroughly enjoyed it.

The zoo is cool lots of different animals to see and learn about but once you have been once you have seen it all.

As a life long Seattleite I am sorry to say that I have taken the zoo for granted and this was my first visit in probably 15 years other then for concerts. They have made such great strides through the years opening up the exhibits so that the animals can rome around, climb trees, swim, etc. and for most it...


More  



Granted I grew up in the Seattle area, and have watched the zoo transform over the years, so to say I have a soft spot for this place is an understatement. More  



We had a great time and walked a lot. Go early for less crowds. There are plenty of places to get food. We were just a little sorry we could not see the Bengal Tiger due to all the adults blocking our way. Lots of fun stuff in the gift shop.

I went yesterday to this zoo because I bought the Seattle CityPass that includes also a ticket for the zoo. I spent 2 hours and a half inside the structure and it was really nice! Big park, a lot of animals divided by their habitat and also a lot pf activities (birds and penguins feeding)!

We go to zoos and aquariums wherever we go, and we go everywhere. After two visits the Woodland Park Zoo has become our favorite. Lots of active, healthy animals in clean and spacious displays. Helpful employees and volunteers everywhere. Some unusual animals, such as magnificent Stellar Sea Eagles, unusual owls, and the best Orangutan exhibit I've ever seen. Playful otters,...

Small beautiful zoo with great walking paths. The nw animals were all very active the day we visited as it was sunny and not too cold. Wolves, bears, otters, and elk all up and about. The exotic animals were staying a bit closer to their warm homes but still nice to see. Lots of family's and even people with dogs...

I loved the 'wild animal park' feel to the zoo. Lots of interesting animals with a worthwhile focus on rehabilitation.
The carousel was a cool bonus!

Most of the animals were not even out. Then, the glass in the Bear and Tiger Exhibits was so scratched, and cloudy that you could barely get a decent picture/photo of the animals. Was quite disappointed in this zoo to say the least. Considering the size of Seattle, this is a rather mundane zoo. I have been to other zoos...

title: Alki Beach, Seattle
review_list:
I love Alki beach, no matter the season, as it always brings back fond memories of my childhood. When it's cold. I can stop at one of the various coffee places for hot cocoa or coffee for my companions, have breakfast or lunch, Blackcomb, or just sit and look at the water.

We enjoy traveling to West Seattle and checking out Alki all throughout the year. In the summer months, it does tend to get a bit crowded, but that is only because it is such a fun place to go during those warm sunny days.

What more could you ask for? This is a great beach area at almost any time of year, with restaurants to relax in, beach to kick back in, the smell of evening firepits burning (get yours early) clear running and walking trails. Try to do it other than a peak summer weekend day as it does get a bit crazy...

One of my favorite places in the Greater Seattle area! Great for picture taking and just to unwind and relax. However, parking is not very good......at all.

The view is great and on a nice day there is a lot to do. There are plenty of places to eat with a view of the water. You can picnic on the beach, play in the sand or play volleyball. There are all kinds of activities for the water and skateboarding, walking, jogging and bicycling on the wide path...

The beach is away from the main city. Has some good restaurant along the shore. The beach is away from all the noise and one can relax and be calm

This was a fun beach. We got food from a food truck and also ate at a local chowder place. The kids liked playing in the sand and it was neat to see a mini statue of liberty.

Alki in West Seattle is a long stretch of beach with a paved walkway, very popular in the summer but great for a walk or run any time of the year. You get the best views of the skyline from Alki, and it is romantic spot to watch the sunset. Stop in at Salty's for a drink or dinner and...


More  



You'll find Alki beach one of your favorite places. Not only will you see lots of people gathering and playing on the beach, bon fires at night during the summer, people roller blading, jogging, walking, boarding up and down the walkway but the restaurants and shops up and down the street are the best for food and drink. It's a...


More  



If you visit Seattle dont miss Alki beach in West Seattle. Great walk way for miles right on the shores of Puget Sound. Ferry boats, shipping, and salt air. Lots of great places to eat, drink, or hang. We like Spuds fish and chips!

title: Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park, Seattle
review_list:
Interesting exhibits about the gold rush and from the time of the gold rush. Rangers available to answer your questions.

This is a tucked away museum but worth a visit. It may take about an hour and a half to see the displays and get insight into the people of the Gold Rush.

This park tells you a lot in a relatively small space. The exhibits are cleverly arranged and make to flow through the display areas very efficient. At least, when there isn't a school group in attendance.
The amazing sets of figures that are presented about the Klondike Gold Rush are staggering. The number of people, the supplies and the amazing...


More  



This was recommended to us as a free, small history lesson. We were there about 45 minutes, and we learned a lot about the Klondike Gold Rush and those involved in it! Great for families!

Very well laid out exhibits. They do have a strong school field trip program, which would have been annoying if there had been students there, but the place was pretty much empty. Rangers were very receptive to my remark that their picture of the Tlingit, while historically accurate, gave a mis-impression of traditional Tlingit houses.

This museum ties Canadian and US history together through the development of the Klondike gold rush and Seattle. It's free, which is good, because you'll pay dearly for parking. The museum has a gold panning exhibition at 11:00. It is kid friendly and has two different booklets for children to complete while going through the museum. The 20 min. introductory...


More  



While strolling around Pioneer Square, we popped into this little museum. The 20 minute video was excellent. It presented the story of four different individuals involved in the Yukon Gold Rush. We can away with a real feel for that time period. For such a small museum, it is a real gem.

This museum is a bit out of the way but worth the small walk. The story is an eyeopener and nicely complements anything you might have learned about Seattle's history when you took the underground tour (do that, it's worth it). Seattle prospered on the back of the gold rush to Klondike, and despite the fact that so many took...


More  



This was a pretty cool museum. It told all about the people who went up to the Klondike in search for gold, showed all the rations they needed to take, and also told you what the gold hunters wish they would have known; that there wasn't that much gold there by the time people rushed there!

This is by no means the largest Historical Park, in fact it may be the smallest. The exhibits are well laid out and explained. The golden eagle pass is good here and a great diversion from Pioneer Square.

title: Gas Works Park, Seattle
review_list:
Wonderful views of Lake Union and the Seattle skyline. Beautiful place to walk or picnic. (Or, on July 4th, to join a billion other people to watch the fireworks display.)

Great place to take pictures lots of cool old machinery. Stay away after dark frequented by homeless folks.

What a great place to watch the 4th of July fireworks, have a picnic, fly kites, watch the boats floating by and observe at sunset.

Fun because of the lovely views of Lake Union and Seattle, with lots of open space for picnics and kite flying.
Funky because of this big old gas plant that dominates the area.
Wonderful place for an outing with family and friends on a sunny day.

Great gem of Seattle, biked down to the park and was astounded at the sights! Great historic preservation with an artistic installation of the old industry. The Park is teaming with blackberry bushes just ripe for the picking and peaople are teaming with great spirits.

Went to Fremont and stopped at the park on my way back to Seattle- glad I did- park has great views of downtown.

nice park with a great view. came here to explore with my kids and had fun. great place to take awesome pictures

I wasn't sure what I expected here but I felt a bit underwhelmed. I walked from Fremont and it felt a bit sketchy at time walking alone as a woman to get there. It was not well signed getting in the area. Once there I basically stood at the top of the hill, took a few pictures and left. Maybe...


More  



I went in January so it was cold, a bit rainy, and windy. Still - the views of downtown and Lake Union were great. The gas works is fenced off so all you can do is look at it and take photos. If it was warmer I would definitely bring a kite or a picnic and plan to spend a...


More  



There's not much to do at Gas Works park, but if you're looking for a perfect spot to see the Seattle skyline, this is it! Float planes come and land in Lake Union, and there's lots of green space for a picnic!

title: Pike Place Fish Market, Seattle
review_list:
This is not just a fish market, it's a consortium of booths and stalls selling all sorts of other foods and sundries. Not to miss if it's a first trip to Seattle.

Commenting solely on their presentation, the fish look fresh, the staff seem friendly, and the service seems top-notch. From a tourist's perspective, I think everyone should visit the unique market during their Seattle visit. From a customer's perspective (though I have never purchased their fish), I am impressed with their selection of fish and customer service.

The world-famous home of flying fish, Pike Place Fish Market is one of Seattle's most beloved tourist attractions.
When someone purchases a fish, one of them will throw it in the air to another to be wrapped up for the customer.
It was amazing! A must see.

In town for business meeting and as luck would have it our meeting room overlooked this amazing, busy fish market with numerous shops, street entertainment, and especially the fish mongers throwing fish! Plus a gigantic brass pig. What more could you ask for! Produce and fish displays were gorgeous. Perhaps monk fish scared a few kids. Really a treat.

This is definitely a must-do in Seattle. Loved walking around seeing the sights and the sounds of the fish market. You can do taste testing and people watch. There's tons of food booths to explore and local delicacies to see. The flowers here are AMAZING and cheap! Loved it. The only thing to be aware of is there's some homeless...


More  



Great place. So many things to see. Many different types of food and flowers. Great fish throwing! Places to sit down and eat too.

If you cast a cold eye on it, then it is a very nice market hall, which offers basically anything you need. What makes it special, is it's world fame and the stall owners are very aware of it and try to keep the ball rolling.

Fresh food abounds and great people watching. It was fairly crowded on a late Monday morning when we went, but I expect it's always somewhat crowded there. Being from out of town I didn't buy much, but there is a fantastic variety of fresh food here for the locals at this indoor market.

This fish market is located in the center of Pike Place Market. Behind the market brass pig! Fresh fish galore. From lobster to crab and everything in between fresh daily from the sound and ocean. The employees throw the purchased fish back and forth to be priced, wrapped and sold. It is quite a spectacle you do not want to...


More  



The guys here are great! They were friendly, helpful and funny! They gave us huge samples of smoked salmon to try and threw our fish up to the counter to be fileted. Can't wait to cook it up when we get home. Traveling 3 hours by car, so they packed it on ice. Must stop when in town!

title: Seattle Art Museum, Seattle
address: 1300 1st Avenue, Between Union & University Street, Seattle, WA 98101-2902
review_list:
I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the Seattle Art Museum. The variety of exhibits would satisfy almost any museum-goer. Art ranged from African cultural masks to Pacific Northwest glass blowing, to paintings by masters.

Gorgeous modern and light filled museum. Filled with outrageously modern exhibits like suspended cars.

You can go and have a great time, with the family or alone, they have many rooms to visit you better have time to go there, and see everything.

There are many places to see in downtown Seattle, the waterfront Ferris wheel, the Pike Place Market, Nordstrom...But, for me it is SAM the Seattle Art Museum that really makes the trip worthwhile. There is a large selection of ethnic art from many cultures, modern art, and diverse special exhibitions, which the curators deftly select to enhance the experience and...


More  



This museum has a good collection of works by local Northwest artists and also artifacts of Northwest Indians. If you're looking for a place with a broad survey of western art, you'll be disappointed.

This is an okay museum. It isn't as big as it looks from the outside. I wanted to take a quick look through and had heard it was free. Woman at the desk had my bag checked but didn't mention anything about needing a ticket or a suggested donation. Went to the stairs and got stopped and turned around. I...


More  



The only reason I am giving this 4 stars is because the impressionist section (pretty large) happened to be closed when I visited. Having said that, they have a suggested amount for donation, but you can pay your own price.
I enjoyed what was open in the museum, and was lucky enough to get to experience an event, "The Art...


More  



Not sure how large the permanent collection of SAM is, but the museum can't but show a fraction. Always innovative exhibits in rotation.

Every second Thursday of the month, there is a free jazz concert with local musicians in the main lobby. The performances are recorded and aired 10 days later on Northwest Jazz on KPLU on Sunday at 2 p.m. These are always top notch musicians and they do a full 2 hours, starting at 7:30. There is a small cash bar...


More  



It was so crowded, that oftentimes there were 4 layers of people trying to catch a glimpse of a painting in the Impressionist Exhibit.

title: Lake Washington, Seattle
review_list:
It's one of the things that makes the Seattle area special is Lake Washington. Spanning from Bothell to Renton and across to Seattle. Connecting the eastern shore of Seattle to the western suburbs. It's stunning view and recreation area for many Seattlites and there guests. Lots of public parks on the lake to enjoy. Many have Kayaks to rent to...


More  



Love to see all the sail boats and try to figure out where Bill Gates lives. Always amazes me how on one side of the floating bridge the water is calm and on the other side the waves are crashing into the bridge

This lake is vast, with activities ranging from sailing, to kayaking, to canoeing to swimming, plus walking trails, bicycling and several public beaches. Most of the lakefront is private property, but there is plenty of public access. If you live in Seattle, this is your lake.

Washington Lake washes up the shores of Seattle to present the city with an amazing natural beauty. The sunset on the lake is spectacular to watch specially from Columbia towers or from the Space Needle. If you are scared of heights then just walk along the shores in the evening.

the area around Lake Washington is beautiful, many paths and beautiful sights to see. Great area in my opinion

Boating, rowing, kayaking, even float planes. And don't for get all the local parks for swimming in the summer. Many trails near it and scenic roads, but mostly residential.

Its very calm and serene. The lake can be accessed by a drive and you can visit Kirkland waterfront too before going.

We did a two hour trip around the lake on a fairly large craft. Sat up top and watched sea planes taking off or landing nearby. Reasonably good commentary throughout. Sailed pass Gas works park, which didn't look my cup of tea and large numbers of floating homes before going through a canal into the Lake Union where we sailed...


More  



It's a beautiful place to spend the day. You can rent paddle boats, and other activities. Walk the path along the lake and just hang out in the big park area with swimming on a hot day.

Beautiful lake and scenery. Makes you feel that you are not in a big city; It is a gateway from the city to the sound and you can see the locks in operations.

title: Seattle Great Wheel, Seattle
review_list:
We walked down to the wheel at dusk and opted to skip the ride line and just enjoy the view from the nearby dock. It looked beautiful as the sky darkened. We intended to return the next day, but it was cloudy and cool, so we skipped it. I'll wait for a sunny, clear day to drop $16 for the...

We went onto the Great Wheel last summer after we found ourselves on a walk down along the waterfront one afternoon. The ride is just long enough that you get a great view of the water, mountains and skyline of Seattle. You're up high enough that you can appreciate the views without someone getting queasy because it's super high up...

This is a very expensive ferris wheel, but I thought it was worth it. The pod was very sturdy and did not move too much. We happened to go during sunset, which was a great treat.
The end photo was a must buy, but also expensive.
It went around 3 times and lasted a decent amount of time.

This is essentially a tourist trap. If you don't get the VIP pass the lines takes hours at times. If you spend the stupid amount of money for the Vip pass. Then you go to the front of the line get to sit in the shade. But it's not worth the price.

We didn't know what to expect, and were very happy with the outcome. My husband, and 16 year old son loved the views, and experience. The line was a little bit of a wait, but not bad.

A beautiful view on a clear day. You have plenty of time to take photos as they stop the wheel to board.

I really enjoyed it and the women that were with us were great, doing little screams when we tried to rock it a little. There is a lot of glass so you do feel like when you look over the edge of something. The bad is that the line was very long

Rainey day when we visited but we had awesome views, rain, sunshine and a beautiful rainbow. Even when the wind hit very little movement felt in the cabin. It was a smooth ride with a variety of weather and experiences. My husband was a little nervous of the height but enjoyed it very much.

$13 a person for "at least" two spins around the wheel. The view was pretty, but a large building blocks the space needle for most of the ride. We rode at night, perhaps during the day you would be able to see Mt. Ranier which would make the ride more interesting. As it was, I would not recommend this activity...

Wow. Loved this ride. You are totally enclosed in the clear cabin. It was warm on a cold day. This is a high ferris wheel so be prepared not to look down if you are afraid of heights. title: Victoria Clipper, Seattle

After kayaking in the San Juan Islands and spending a couple of days in Victoria BC sight-seeing, my wife and I were looking for a quick way to return to Seattle for our flight home to Colorado. Not wanting to retrace our steps on the Washington State Ferry system back to Anacortes, I found the Victoria Clipper which makes a...

title: Seattle Aquarium, Seattle

the views were great but it was raining, what can you do, overall still great if rain doesnt bother u than your good

title: Lake Union, Seattle
address: North of downtown, south of Fremont, Seattle, WA
review_list:
Lake Union is a pearl in Seattle's crown.
Just South of bustling downtown, the lake provides open space, museums, restaurants, sea planes, sailing opportunities and so much more. The shore is full of boats and houseboats of all sizes.
Whatever side you approach it from offers great views and interesting activity.
Isn't open water wonderful.

Take your time and walk along the wall and enjoy the view. If you get a chance, go to the Ballard Locks and watch the boats come in to the Lake from the Ocean.

We had a good time at Lake Union and took a walk by the lake. We also enjoyed visiting the cafes and shops in the area. Its fun to see the floating boat homes in the area and watching the birds as well.

Lake Union offers many things to see and do. The are coffee shops, restaurants, parks, a museum and much more. Walking is the best way to really experience Lake Union. It's one of the best places to view the fireworks on July 4th.

We took a boat ride around the lake. You get a great view of the downtown, gas works park, and all those awesome floating boat houses. Super cool how much activity is going on throughout this lake, kayaking, boating, etc.

We had an awesome time tooling around during the duck tour however, the trip around Lake Union was awesomely most excellent fun.

A nice relaxing setting,where you can sit or walk around a bit.There is a cafe on hand ( Compass) for a snack.We decided to do the walk round,but it is quite a long way - we managed one side.The Gas Works park is at the far end and worth a visit if you can get there.Along the pathways there are...


More  



I believe Lake Union from around the area of the Swedish Club is before one gets to Freemont. It is a beautiful club for people of Swedish and other Nordic heritage. The members were very friendly and welcoming. the club serves a beautiful Pancake breakfast on the first Sunday of every month. The breakfast comes with Ham, lingonberries. orange juice...


More  



Great area for dining out. Choose from a number of good restaurants and in the summer you may be treated to some good jazz

We are lucky to be staying in a condo overlooking Lake Union. there is a lot of traffic on the lake, seaplanes, paddle boarders, sailboats, pleasure boats of all sizes.

title: Queen Anne Hill, Seattle
review_list:
My dad grew up in QA, and I grew up on the next hill over, Magnolia, so QA is special to me. After ten years in California and 12 years in the Middle East, we're back in the Seattle area, albeit in Redmond.

The view from Queen Anne Hill of Seattle is spectacular! The houses in the neighborhood are quaint and have an awesome view of the Space Needle.

To drive through the area is one of the best drives. Some of the homes are spectacular. Nicely groomed yards.

I love Queen Anne area. I usually always stay at a hotel in this area of Seattle. Convenient and just an overall great neighborhood. Walkable with many restaurants and nightlife.

Very beautiful district where most of the City's rich and affluent live a few celebreties. It has some very stunning house with individual designs...

You can see this hill from anywhere in Seattle downtown, so it's tempting to get up there and look at the city, right? Well, it's actually a great idea. The hill is not that high, a bit over 300 feet and it's only about 1 mile from Space Needle. So if you have an hour or bit more - go...


More  



You will not be disappointed if you decide to get out and explore Queen Anne Hill. The neighborhood is beautiful. It offers excellent views of the sound and the city. There are some very nice small little parks that you will come across.

We were there today 27 Oct 2015 across the day. walking though the avenues and enjoying the sight of well built elegant homes on one side and Seattle views on the other. Would make a very good option for a children's school day out. There is also the added attraction that there is nothing they can spend on !!

We stopped on Queen Anne Hill on a bus tour of Seattle. The view of the skyline was amazing. We went back up to watch the eclipse. What a fun evening we had with moon gazing with the locals.

Great way to walk off all your meals LOL!!
Seriously , beautiful scenery. I enjoyed getting up in the early am, would walk , meditate and drink my coffee

title: Seattle Japanese Garden, Seattle
address: 1075 Lake Washington Blvd E, Seattle, WA 98112
review_list:
Although this one is not so big but it is still beautiful. The trees, shrubs, the pathways, large koi fishes swimming in the ponds and the turtles too just made everything perfect. Always a nature lover so I am always excited to visit gardens when on a trip. Worth a visit if you love nature.

Beautifully designed Japanese garden, lovely pathways and feeding the fish was a very delightful experience.
one can spend hours in this peaceful place!

Maybe it's because i like the japanese aesthetic of perfecting nature, but this spot is pretty special. If you are into gardening or know someone who is, they will appreciate the effort that goes into making this look like a naturally occurring landscape. Great photos around every ben.

Early morning walk. A bit overpriced at $6.00 for a quick walk. However, the walk and the memory is worth a whole lot more than an overpriced cup of Starbucks. Sunny bright day in Seattle, just lucky I suppose.

we went in october but it's beautiful almost year round. Great job keeping everything trimmed and blooming optimally.

I have to say, that even in early winter (November) this is a beautiful and peaceful garden to walk through. Though half the trees don't have leaves, there area still others that stay in foliage and bloom year round here. Plus you have the serenity of the water, the fish and of course the turtles.
In my opinion this is...


More  



The Japanese Garden is always fun to visit. But at it's best in the spring and fall. It's a great place to take friends or family who are visiting Seattle. Normally there is plenty of parking.

Its a very quiet and relaxing spot and the Japanese maples of gold, orange and red were just awesome. The grounds keeping is perfect yet the leaves yet to be raked made for a beautiful sight both on the grass and floating down the streams. Highly recommend you visit during late October time of year.

The Japanese Garden in the Arboretum is absolutely beautiful. There is a small fee to enter the garden, but you can stay and stroll the paths all afternoon or to your heart's desire. It is right across the street from the Washington Park Arboretum (which is free), another great attraction. The garden and arboretum are particularly gorgeous in the fall.

Everything seems so nice. All the garden is in a maple red. So quiet and so cool. It's a good place for family tour, even though frequent rainfalls.

title: Seattle Theater Group- Paramount, Seattle
review_list:
Just attended the opening of "Bullets Over Broadway" at the Paramount Theater.
The acting was first rate, and the live music added to the experience of attending a professional stage production. If you can't make it to Broadway, don't hesitate to experience a local venue that is classy all the way!

Theater was ornate and beautiful. Be advised...many stairs.
Great performance. Would highly recommend. We will be returning in March.

THE place for concerts and musical productions. This theatre has been renovated from the ground up (the free backstage tour is awesome) and has a variety of seating configurations, several bars, and a well-trained staff. It's been amazing to see this theatre grow from its shabby state in the 1970's to the world-class venue it is right now.

STG saved this historic theater from the wrecking ball, restored to it's original glory and hosts the best entertainment you can find anywhere. Register with STG & get advance notice on all the shows. We are particularly fond of Broadway musicals but also love rock & comedy concerts.

Great old theater in the heart of Seattle. It's a landmark of the city and is on the national historic register. It was opened in 1928 as the Seattle Theater. It is owned and operated by the Seattle Theatre Group, and has 3,000 seats. It was renamed the Paramount in the 1930s.It's worth snapping a few pictures.

This is a must see place in Seattle. Seeing a show here is out of this world. The building itself is breathtaking. The shows are awesome.

We went to see Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host which was a brand new experience. We had seats pretty far back but they were fantastic. It is a very historic old venue but it feels really fresh and modern inside. The parking was a little tough but we ended up looping around enough to catch a break fairly...


More  



If/Then, created to showcase her talents, shows the diversity in life based on minor decisions. Wow!

Fantastic show in GORGEOUS THEATRE!!! Broadway touring company with Tony Award-nominated cast is hard to beat, and the performance was excellent. The theatre was worthy of the show.

I have been to the Paramount for a dozen or so broadway shows (most recently If/Then), and it's always a treat. Wonderful staff, great selection of shows, wonderful sound, good views from any seat. The only "down-side" is that this historic theatre had tight/narrow seating and little room by your feet. But I wouldn't let that deter me from seeing...

title: Lake Washington Fish Ladder, Seattle

review_list:
Perfect little swimming hole with Beautiful views. It has a grassy are for frisbee throwing and also rest rooms. The kids enjoyed the playground which is within walking distance. Downtown Leschi is right up the hill. We enjoyed our relaxing time there at the Park

Majestic trees, manicured expanses of grass and beds of fuchsias and roses are everywhere. The park is on a slope, stretching back and up to tennis courts and then continuing via trail deep into the woods. The park is on lake Washington and offers amazing sunsets and views of the Eastside.

title: Kobo, Seattle
review_list:
This is a really nice little shop at the north end of Broadway on Capitol Hill in Seattle.
The special in beautiful ceramic work. If you in the neighborhood it's worth a visit.

this store is a little like a museum - really do like visiting here; sometimes I buy nothing and other times I buy a lot - went there today and got a beautiful handmade cup; a bag; some pencils and a book ... worthwhile and lovely

title: Ship Canal Trail, Seattle

Very nice trail wondering next to the ship canal. Very nice to walk and watch the boats go by. Great way to see the working part of the waterfront.

When you come to Seattle bring your bike, rent one, or lace up your walking shoes.

This gallery (I will have reviewed others as well) in the Pioneer Square district specializes in contemporary painting. The two artists shown when we were there were extremely interesting and of high quality. This gallery participates in the First Thursday art walk in Seattle. Worth a walk to the numerous galleries in this area.

title: Ward Johnson Winery, Seattle
review_list:
We visited on a Paint Night had a blast. Been twice in one month. Wine was really good. Ended up buying bottle's to take home....

A great little urban winery near Pier 91. They have regular Paint Nite where people paint and sip wine in the winery. Staff was very friendly, they were happy to chat with me. Wines were well made and delicious. It was an enjoyable experience tasting here.

yeah its okay and a good place to think and get some relaxation or meditation in and the grounds are nice but i heavily prefer the one in richmond bc (vancouver), i think it is waay nicer

title: Alki Park, Seattle
review_list:
The kids loved the beach. The views of Seattle were spectacular. However the beach itself was very very rocky and could use some imported sand. This place would be awesome!! However we loved it. The ferry to get there and back was quite expensive since we have three kids!

If you are in Seattle you must go check out a sunset here. The beach and little town are lovely. On a sunny day it will be busy, Lively & worth every second.
Reminded me of Mallory Square in Key West except the water is freezing. The views on the other hand will blow you away!!

review_list: I visit Seattle on a regular basis and always check in at the Gallery Mack. It is not far from my other favorite place the Pike Place Market. title: Seattle Tilth Children's Garden, Seattle
review_list: We loved the paintball and the frozen banana stand. Dogs were kept on a leash, apart from spaniels. Bring your old and ancient relatives for a grand old game of spatulynka.

title: Log House Museum, Seattle
review_list: Lovely little museum run by the Southwest Seattle Historical Society, showing the history and origin of West Seattle. No fee, but donations are gladly accepted.

review_list: If you are in this part of town I strongly recommend perusing this gallery. There's always something interesting here.

review_list: Nice stop to meditate and reflect. The architecture is inviting and modern. Whether inside or outside it is a nice place to relax.

review_list: Seattle has a number of great view points but this park is one of the best. Treat yourself to this tour which takes in the (often humorous) story of the city of Seattle. Sometimes it's is amazing what's just under your feet. Guide was absolutely excellent. Tour is not too taxing in distance or stairs. Small size of the group made it feel more exclusive.

This tour -- most of which is under downtown Seattle streets -- is rich in history. It explains early construction in the city, and why the first floors of buildings constructed many years are now one story below street level. We were fortunate to have an excellent guide.

I am so glad we decided to go on this tour. It made me appreciate Seattle even more than it did already. We were so fortunate to enjoy the tour with our tour guide Carla, I was very intrigued by her knowledge. Thank you again Carla for making this tour so wonderful.

This was a really fun trip for my wife and I. My son wasn't so interested. (teenager) However, I would highly recommend it. They take you under the current streets to what is referred to as the underground. The history of Seattle is shared, and that is what made it interesting for us.
